Cloning and functional characterization of a TMC-like channel gene and protein in the crayfish
Astacus leptodactylus ( Eschscholtz, 1823 )

sec.title: A B ST R A CT
sec.p:
Ion channels gated selectively by mechanical stimulus are the key elements of mechanosensation. Several genes have been associated with putative mechanosensitive ion channels or mechanosensitive channel complexes. Transmembrane channel (TMC)-like protein is one of those candidate proteins that have been explored in mammals and several invertebrates. The presence and possible function of TMC related genes has not been investigated yet in crustaceans. In the present work an mRNA coding TMC-like protein was firstly cloned in
Astacus leptodactylus ( Eschscholtz, 1823 )
( Decapoda : Astacidea: Astacidae ) and expressed in HEK293T cells. Three-dimensional structural calculations of the protein predicted a channel. Functional studies, however, indicated that the mechanosensitivity of the transfected HEK293T cells is similar to that in the control cells. It was concluded that a TMC-like protein is present in the crayfish but future studies are necessary to define its function.

sec.title: KEY WORDS: cloning , Crustacea , mechanosensation , transmembrane channel
INTRODUCTION
sec.p: Cells are susceptible to many different kinds of stimuli, one of which is mechanical force. Some cells have evolved to sense mechanical force specifically, and it has been shown that the mechanical stimulus evokes ionic currents in some cells due to an increase in the membrane conductance. The change in the conductance is generated by a unique type of ion channel, gated preferably by the mechanical force only, classified as mechanically activated or mechanosensitive ion channels.

sec.title: MATERIALS AND METHODS
sec.p:
An mScarlet backbone was used in plasmid synthesis. The original plasmid, containing an SCN1A fragment, a gift from Dr. Al George (Northwestern University Feinberg School of Medicine, Chicago, IL, USA ) (see
), was modified by substituting the SCN1A fragment by the cloned TMC mRNA. ‘F1_tmc_mScarlet’ and ‘R1_tmc_mScarlet’ primers having matching tails for the plasmid were designed for the In-Fusion assembly reaction. We used NotI and PvuI enzymes to linearize the plasmid and ‘F1_tmc_mScarlet’ and ‘R1_tmc_mScarlet’ primers to amplify the cDNA product. Using In-Fusion HD Cloning Kit (Takara Bio, Shiga , Japan ) the ‘tmc_mScarlet’ plasmid was generated and cloned in E.coli bacterial cultures. HEK293T cells were cultured in a 35 mm Petri dish with high glucose Gibco Dulbecco’s Modified Eagle Medium (Thermo-Fisher Scientific, Waltham, MA, USA ) with 5% fetal bovine serum and kept in an incubator at 37 °C, 5% CO 2. HEK293T cells were transfected with the plasmid using a kit (Lipofectamine 3000, Thermo-Fisher Scientific). Dishes containing cells with a red fluorescent emission were considered as the transfected group. We discarded the culture medium and cells were washed with phosphate buffer saline solution (PBS). The cell solution was replaced with 1 ml PBS (137 mM NaCl, 2.7 mM KCl, 10 mM Na2HPO4, and 1.8 mM KH2PO4). We loaded 1 ml of the calcium indicator dye solution (Fluo-4 AM 2.5 µM in PBS) into the cells by incubation at room temperature for 20 min for a final dye concentration of 1.25 µM. Dishes were positioned under a confocal laser scanning microscope and calcium specific emission signal was recorded in response to mechanical stimulation. Cells were mechanically stimulated by either gently poking with a blunt electrode, pulses of fluid jets, or an osmotic shock. Osmotic shock was induced by increasing NaCl concentration, up to 167 mM, by adding a known volume of concentrated NaCl solution to develop shrinkage. A calcium-specific emission signal from the entire view field was recorded at a continuous 128 × 128 pixel per frame scanning mode at ~4 Hz. Excitation wavelength was 488 nm and a longpass filter of 505 nm was used for collecting the emission. During acquisition, the confocal pinhole was set to a fully open configuration to collect the maximum signal. Designated region of interests (ROIs) encircling either a single transfected or untransfected cell were selected for data extraction from the recorded images. Peak amplitude of the emission signals was measured for calculations and statistical tests. Recordings were baseline corrected and peak amplitudes were compared in MATLAB environment by using a two sample t-test.

sec.title: RESULTS
sec.p: The RACE-PCR experiments resulted in ~700 and ~1,500 base pairs of fragments in size for the 5 ʹ and 3 ʹ ends, respectively. Sequencing of these fragments revealed the complete TMC mRNA including the open reading frame (ORF) and the untranslated regions in both ends (GenBank accession number: ON604003) ( Fig. 1B ).

In order to compare the expression level of ganglia and muscle tissues we used available hundreds of millions of short reads of cDNA libraries. Equalized number of short reads were Bowtie mapped to TMC mRNA sequence in DNASTAR platform. Short read hits were compered. Calculations indicated a fourfold larger mRNA expression in the ganglia tissues.

The three-dimensional structure of the cloned channel protein was calculated by using various open access web based facilities. Results obtained in I-TASSER and AlphaFold were rather limited due to the size restrictions of the platforms, but we obtained a successful calculation of the complete structure in the SWISS-MODEL platform. The quaternary structure quality estimation (QSQE), sequence similarity, and coverage scores of the calculation were 0.33, 0.33, and 0.73, respectively ( Fig. 3 ). The calculated three dimensional structure of the cloned protein is very similar to that of
Caenorhabditis elegans
tmc-1 protein NP_508221.3), but the
C. elegans
tmc-1 protein is much larger in size compared to the other TMC sequences including the cloned protein in
Astacus leptodactylus
. As shown in Fig. 3D , the calculated structure of the cloned sequence aligned well to the
C. elegans
tmc-1 protein structure. The SWISS-Model homology calculation had ten transmembrane domains as in the
C. elegans
tmc-1 protein. The calculated pore forming transmembrane segments of the
C. elegans
tmc-1 protein, TM4, and TM8, aligned to the segments between 220–247 and 648–670 residues of the cloned protein, respectively.

The Fluo-4 AM-loaded HEK293T cells were poked with a blunt microelectrode to test if the cloned channel is sensitive to mechanical stimulus. A rise in calcium-specific emission signal in response to mechanical stimulation was considered as an indicator of a calcium influx through the mechanosensitive channels. The experiments were conducted on both transfected and control cells and results were compared. As shown in Figure 5A , the results were inconclusive as they failed to show any statistically significant difference between the transfected and control cells in these sample sizes. Peak amplitudes of the recorded calcium signals were statistically similar in both groups (control group 31.81 ± 12.86, mean ± SD, N = 5, transfected cells 21.36 ± 16.59, mean ± SD, N = 5, P = 0.29). Transfected cells were mechanically stimulated by application of fluid jets from a micro-pipette that were produced by using a pneumatic injector. The maximum amplitudes of the evoked calcium response to fluid jets were similar when the results from test and control cells were compared (control group 6.57 ± 4.10, mean ± SD, N = 6, transfected cells 11.99 ± 12.08, mean ± SD, N = 6, P = 0.32) ( Fig. 5B ). The possible effects of extracellular sodium concentration were investigated in another experimental group. The bath solution was substituted with a solution containing 167 mM sodium while the calcium sensitive emission was acquired continuously. The amplitudes of the change in the signal were similar in both groups (control group 1.07 ± 1.07, mean ± SD, N = 4, transfected cells 3.76 ± 2.85, mean ± SD, N = 4, P = 0.12) ( Fig. 5C ).

sec.title: DISCUSSION
sec.p: Although an mRNA was cloned, coding a protein similar in sequence and structure to those of the mechanosensitive TMC family proteins, functional studies nevertheless do not indicate that the transfected HEK293T cells gained any additional statistically significant mechanosensitive component as compared to the control cells. The sample sizes, particularly for fluid jet and osmotic shock applications, might not have been enough for a statistically significant result. Additional research is needed to define the function of the cloned crayfish TMC-like protein.
